Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery vessel, possibly a dinos; yellowish slip; exterior, from top: possibly tips of rays; narrow band; animal procession (back of boar and tail of bull) to right; pendant roundel and triangle and dotted cross as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Williams (2006a, 128) notes that Chian dinos sherds are often mistaken for oinochoai because of the lack of slip on the interior surface. The thickness of the sherd suggests it was a large vessel.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 110, no. 321.5, pl. 34)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 253, no. 410)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0017) (phase 2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 219, no. 60)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4682 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
